variant.question: The Minimum Descent Altitude/Height (MDA/MDH) is:

options.text: A specified altitude (A) or height (H) in a non-precision or circling approach below which descent may not be made without visual reference
A specified altitude (A) or height (H) in a precision approach below which descent may not be made without visual reference
A specified altitude (A) or height (H) in a precision approach at which, if the visual reference required to continue the approach has not been established, a missed approach must be initiated

A specified altitude (A) or height (H) in a non-precision or circling approach at which, if the visual reference required to continue the approach has not been established, a missed approach must be initiated

At least 2000 ft above the highest obstacle located within 6 km of the estimated position of the aircraft.

An incident with respect to safe terrain separation occurs during night VMC in Class G airspace. The aircraft involved in the incident is operating on an IFR flight plan. Considering this scenario, which of the statements below is correct with respect to terrain separation?

options.text: In uncontrolled airspace, the Pilot-in-Command is solely responsible for ensuring safe terrain separation.
For all IFR flights, irrespective of the airspace class, maintaining safe terrain separation is the combined responsibility of the Pilot in Command and the Air Traffic Controller.
Only during VMC is the Pilot-In-Command responsible for safe terrain separation.
When operating at night in class G airspace, safe terrain separation is the responsibility of the Air Traffic Controller issuing radar vectors.

The pilot should...

options.text: Turn left to head 285°(M) and descend to 2300 feet. The minimum radar vectoring altitude may be below MSA.
Maintain heading and altitude, and request new descent instructions, because 2300 feet is below MSA.
Turn left to head 285°(M) but maintain 3000 feet and request new descent instructions, because 2300 feet is below MSA.
Turn left to head 285°(T) and descend to 2500 feet altitude, because this is the MSA. Inform the controller about the change.

Item 8 of your ATC flight plan contains the letter Z. Shortly after your VFR departure from EDTL (Lahr, N48°22’ E007°50’) while flying towards reporting point ECHO you request an IFR clearance. After verification of your transponder code, the ATC controller confirms a positive radar identification and inform you "IFR starts now" followed by other instructions. You are still in VMC conditions when passing 1 500 ft AGL when you read-back the ATC clearance. Considering the above scenario, which of the following statements is true?

options.text: When issuing an IFR clearance inside controlled airspace, the ATC controller assumes responsibility for terrain separation.
IFR flight inside class E airspace is NOT allowed.
In VMC conditions while flying IFR inside controlled airspace the Pilot-in-Command is solely responsible for terrain separation.
The ATC flight plan should have been filled with the letter I (for IFR) in item 8.

The minimum holding altitude (MHA) provides a minimum obstacle clearance of at least ___ in the holding area where the terrain elevation is up to 2 000 ft.

A light twin engined aircraft departs La Fleche aerodrome (LFAL) in France to route across to Nantes Airport (LFRS). Due to weather conditions the aircraft receives clearance to cross Nantes control zone, Class D airspace, IFR at 2000 ft with the pilot's own routing. Which of the following is correct regarding the responsibility for terrain separation?

options.text: The Pilot-in-Command is always responsible for terrain separation, except when following vectors under IFR.
The Air Traffic Controller is responsible for terrain separation when giving the aircraft an altitude to fly under IFR.
The Air Traffic Controller is responsible for terrain separation for all IFR flights in Class A, B, C or D airspace.
The Pilot-in-Command is always responsible for terrain separation.

options.text: Between radials 177° and 130°, MSA is 1 700 ft.

variant.question: The Minimum Safe Sector Altitude (MSA) is:

options.text: Published on instrument charts and gives the lowest altitude which may be used which will provide a minimum clearance of 1000 ft above all objects within  a sector of a circle of 25NM radius centred on a radio aid (or fix).
Published on instrument approach charts and gives the minimum altitude that provides a 1000 ft. vertical clearance from obstacles within 25 nm of the aerodrome.
Published on airways approach charts and gives the minimum altitude that provides a 1000 ft. vertical clearance from obstacles within 25 nm of the airway.
Published on instrument approach charts and gives the minimum altitude that provides a 1000 ft. vertical clearance from obstacles within 50 nm of the navigation facility.

options.text: Services for a temporary tower are available Friday 4th November and Saturday 5th November 2013, between 14:00 and 21:00, and frequency 121.0 will be used to control arriving and departing aircraft and for issuing clearances.

An additional frequency of 121.0 is temporarily available for a tower to control arriving and departing aircraft for designed runway(s) and for issuing clearances on Friday 4th November and Saturday 5th November 2013, between 14:00 and 21:00.

Tower services to control arriving and departing aircraft and issuing clearances on the frequency 121.0 will be temporarily unavailable Friday 4th November and Saturday 5th November 2013, between 14:00 and 21:00.
